editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Hannah Bredar

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

Fletcher, John, 1579-1625,

note.p: Not in fact by John Fletcher, but by James Shirley.
Title page partly from the same setting of type as John Fletcher's "The night-walker" (STC 11072).
Reproduction of the original in the Folger Shakespeare Library.

div.p: As it was presented by her majesty's servants at the private house in Drury lane.
London, printed by Tho. Cotes, for Andrew Crooke, and William Cooke. and are to be sold at the sign of the green dragon, in Paul's churchyard. 1640.

lg.l: Since 'tis become the title of our play,
A woman once in a coronation may
With pardon, speak the prologue, give as free
A welcome to the theater, as he
That with a little beard, a long black cloak,
With a starched face, and supple leg hath spoke
Before the plays the twelvemonth, let me then ▪
Present a welcome to these gentlemen,
If you be kind, and noble, you will not
Think the worse of me for my petticoat.
But to the play, the poet bade me tell
His fears first in the title, lest it swell
Some thoughts with expectation of a strain,
That but once could be seen in a King's reign,
This coronation, he hopes you may
See often, while the genius of his play,
Doth prophesy the conduits may run wine,
When the day's triumph's ended, and divine
Brisk nectar swell his temples to a rage,
With something of more price to invest the stage ▪
There rests but to prepare you, that although
It be a coronation, there doth flow
No undermirth, such as doth lard the scene
For course delight, the language here is clear.
And confident our poet bade me say,
He'll bate you but the folly of a play.
For which although dull souls his pen despise,
Who thinks it yet too early to be wise.
The nobler will thank his muse, at least
Excuse him, cause his thought aimed at the best,
but we conclude not, it dost rest in you.
To censure poet, play, and prologue too.
But what have I omitted? is there not
A blush upon my cheeks that I forget
The ladies, and a female prologue too?
Your pardon noble gentlewomen, you
Were first within my thoughts, I know you sit
As free, and high commissioners of wit,
Have clear, and active souls, nay though the men
Were lost in your eyes, they'll be found again,
You are the bright intelligences move,
And make a harmony this sphere of love,
Be you propitious then, our poet says,
Our wreath from you, is worth their grove of bays:

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Make way for my lord protector.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: I like your diligent waiting, where's Lisimachus?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: The Queen looks pleasant
This morning, does she not?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I ever found
Her gracious smiles on me.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: She does consult
Her safety in't, for I must tell thee boy,
But in the assurance of her love to thee,
I should advance thy hopes another way,
And use the power I have in Epire, to
Settle our own, and uncontrolled greatness;
But since she carries herself so fairly,
I am content to expect, and by her marriage
Secure thy fortune, that's all my ambition
now, be still careful in thy applications
To her, I must attend other affairs,
Return, and use what art thou canst to lay
More charms of love upon her.

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.l: I presume
She always speaks the language of her heart,
And I can be ambitious for no more
Happiness on earth than she encourages
Me to expect.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: It was an act becoming
The wisdom of her father to engage
A tie between our families, and she
Hath played her best discretion to allow it;
But we lose time in conference, wait on her,
And be what thou wert born for, King of Epire,Exit.
I must away.

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.l: Success ever attend you.
Is not the Queen yet coming forth?

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.l: Your servant,
You may command our duties,
This is the court star Philocles.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: The star that we must sail by.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.l: All must borrow
A light from him, the young Queen directs all
Her favours that way.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: He's a noble gentleman
And worthy of his expectations:
Too good to be the son of such a father.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Peace, remember he is lord protector.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: We have more need of heaven's protection
I'th mean time, I wonder the old King
Did in his life design him for the office.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.l: He might suspect his faith, I have heard when
The King who was no Epirote advanced
His claim, Cassander, our protector now,
Young then, opposed him toughly with his faction,
But forced to yield had fair conditions,
And was declared by the whole state next heir
if the King wanted issue; our hopes only
Thrived in this daughter.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Whom but for her smiles
And hope of marriage with Lisimachus,
His father by some cunning had removed
Ere this.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.l: Take heed, the arras may have ears
I should not weep much if his grace would hence
Remove to heaven.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I prithee what should he do there?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: And the sky too, ere I get one stair higher
While he's in place.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Lisander, Philocles,
How looks the day upon us? where's the Queen?

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: None but the young lord Lisimachus.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis no treason
If a man wish himself a courtier
Of such a possibility: he has
The mounting fate.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I would his father were
Mounted toth' gallows.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He has a path fair enough,
If he survive by title of his father.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: The Queen will hasten his ascent.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou wod'st become rarely the petticoat,
What wod'st thou do?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Why, I would marry
My gentleman usher, and trust all the strength
And burden of my state upon his legs,
Rather than be called wife by any son
Of such a father.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.l: Come let's leave this subject,
We may find more secure discourse; when saw
you young Arcadius, lord Macarius' nephew?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: There's a spark, a youth moulded for a favourite,
The Queen might do him honour.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Favourite, 'tis too cheap a name, there were a match
Now for her virgin blood.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.l: Must every man
That has a hansome face or leg feed such
Ambition: I confess I honour him,
He has a nimble soul, and gives great hope
To be no woman-hater, dances handsomely,
Can court a lady powerfully, but more goes
Toth' making of a prince? he's here
And's uncle.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Save you gentlemen, who can direct me
To find my lord protector?

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.l: He was here
Within this half hour, young Lisimachus
His son is with the Queen.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: There let him compliment,
I have other business, ha? Arcadius!

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Observed you with what eyes Arcadius
And he saluted, their two families
Will hardly reconcile.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Seleucus carries
Himself too roughly, with what pride and scorn
He passed by 'em.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.l: The tother with less show
Of anger carries pride enough in's soul,
I wish 'em all at peace, Macarius looks
Are without civil war, a good old man,
The old King loved him well, Seleucus' father
Was as dear to him, and maintained the character
Of an honest lord through Epire: that two men
So loved of others, should be so unwelcome
To one another.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: The Queen was not wont to send for me.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: The reason's to herself,
It will become your duty to attend her.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Save you gentlemen, what novelty
Does the court breath today?

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.l: None sir, the news
That took the last impression is, that you
Purpose to leave the kingdom, and those men,
That honour you, take no delight to hear it.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I have ambition to see the difference
Of courts, and this may spare; the delights
At home do surfeit, and the mistress whom
We all do serve is fixed upon one object,
Her beams are too much pointed, but no country
Shall make me lose your memories.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Your lordship honoured me,
I have no blessing in his absence.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: We must not
Give any licence.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: If your majesty
Would please.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: We are not pleased, it had become your duty,
To have first acquainted us, ere you declared
Your resolution public, is our court
Not worth your stay?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: We shall find
Employment at home for you, do not lose us.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Madam I then write myself blessed on earth
When I may do you service.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Madam you have blessed me,
Nothing but your command could interpose to
Stay him.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Lisimachus
You must not leave us.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.l: Nothing but Lisimachus? has she not
ta'ne a philtre?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Nay pray be covered, ceremony from you.
Must be excused,

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Not your love?
I know you would not have me look upon
Your person as a courtier, not as favourite,
That title were too narrow to express
How we esteem you.

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.l: The least of all
These names from you madam, is grace enough.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.p: Yet here you would not rest.

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.l: Not if you please?
To say there is a happiness beyond,
And teach my ambition how to make it mine,
Although the honours you already have
Let fall upon your servant, exceed all
My merit; I have a heart is studious
To reach it with desert, and make if possible
Your favours mine by justice, with your pardon.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: We are confident this needs no pardon sir,
But a reward to cherish your opinion,
And that you may keep warm your passion,
Know we resolve for marriage, and if
I had another gift, beside myself,
Greater, in that you should discern, how much
My heart is fixed.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.p: But I cannot resolve when this shall be,

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.l: How madam? do not make me dream of heaven
And wake me into misery, if your purpose
Be, to immortalize your humble servant,
Your power on earth's divine, princes are here
The copies of eternity, and create
When they but will our happiness.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I shall
Believe you mock me in this argument,
I have no power.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.p: I must obey, your fathers my protector.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: When I am absolute, Lisimachus,
Our power and titles meet, before, we are but
A shadow, and to give you that were nothing,

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.l: Excellent Queen,
My love took no original from state,
Or the desire of other greatness,
Above what my birth may challenge modestly,
I love your virtues; mercenary souls
Are taken with advancement, you've an empire
Within you, better than the worlds, to that
Looks my ambition.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Tother is not fit
To be despised, cosmography allows
Epire a place ith' map, and know till I
Possess what I was born to, and alone
Do grasp the kingdom's sceptre, I account
Myself divided, he that marries me
Shall take an absolute Queen to his warm bosom,
My temples yet are naked, until then
Our loves can be but compliments, and wishes,
Yet very hearty ones.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Madam, a gentleman has an humble suit,

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: 'Tis in your power to grant, you are protector,
I am not yet a Queen.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Madam to reconcile two families
That may unite, both counsels and their blood
To serve your crown.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Macarius, and Eubulus
That by are inveterate malice to each other.
It grew, as I have heard ▪ upon the question
Which some of either family had made,
Which of their fathers was the best commander:
If we believe our storeys, they have both
Deserved well of our state, and yet this quarrel
Has cost too many lives, a severe faction.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: But I'll propound a way to plant a quiet
And peace in both our houses, which are torn
With their dissensions, and lose the glory
Of their great names, my blood speaks my relation
To Eubulus, and I wish my veins were emptied
To appease their war.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Thou hast a noble soul,
This is a charity above thy youth,
And it flows bravely from thee, name the way.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: In such a desperate cause, a little stream
Of blood might purge the foulness of their hearts
If you'll prevent a deluge.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Let but your majesty consent, that two
May with their personal valour undertake
The honour of their family, and determine
Their difference.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: This rather will enlarge
Their hate, and be a means to call more blood
Into the stream.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Not if both families
Agree, and swear —

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.p: And who shall be the champions.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I beg the honour, for Eubulus' cause
To be engaged, if any for Macarius,
Worthy to wager heart with mine, accept it,
I am confident, Arcadius
For honour would direct me to his sword,
Will not deny, to stake against my life
His own, if you vouchsafe us privilege.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: You are the expectation and top boughs
Of both your houses, it would seem injustice,
To allow a civil war to cut you off,
And yourselves the instruments, besides
You appear a soldier, Arcadius
Hath no acquaintance yet with rugged war,
More fit to drill a lady then expose
His body to such dangers: a small wound
Ith' head may spoil the method of his hair ▪
Whose curiosity exacts more time
Than his devotion, and who knows but he
May lose his ribbon by it in his lock,
Dear as his saint, with whom he would exchange
His head, for her gay colours; then his band
May be disordered, and transformed from lace
To cutwork, his rich clothes be discomplexion
With blood, beside the unfashionable slashes,
And at the next festival take physic,
Or put on black, and mourn for his slain breeches:
His hands cased up in gloves all night, and sweat
Pomatum, the next day may be endangered
To blisters with a sword, how can he stand
Upon his guard, who hath fiddlers in his head,
To which, his feet must ever be a dancing.
Beside a falsify may spoil his cringe,
Or making of a leg, in which consists
Much of his court perfection.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Is this character
Bestowed on him?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: It something may concern the gentleman,
Whom if you please to challenge
To dance, play on the lute, or sing.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: He shall not want those will maintain him
For any sum.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: You are my sovereign,
I dare not think, yet I must speak somewhat,
I shall burst else, I have no skill in jigs,
nor tumbling.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Nor was I born a minstrel, and in this you have
So infinitely disgraced Arcadius,
But that I have heard another character,
And with your royal licence do believe it,
I should not think him worth my killing.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Does she not jeer me;
I shall talk treason presently, I find it
At my tongues end already, this is an
Affront, I'll leave her.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.p: Come back, do you know Arcadius?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I ha' changed but little breath with him, our persons
Admit no familiarity, we were
Born to live both at distance, yet I ha' seen him
Fight, and fight bravely.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: When the spirit of wine
Made his brain valiant he fought bravely.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Although he be my enemy, should any
Of the gay flies that buzz about the court,
Sit to catch trouts ith' ▪ summer, tell me so,
I durst in any presence but your own.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Tell him he were not honest.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I see Seleucus thou art resolute,
And I but wronged Arcadius, your first
Request is granted, you shall fight, and he
That conquers be rewarded to confirm
First place and honour to his family:
Is it not this you plead for?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I wish thy sword may open
His wanton veins, Macarius is too popular,
And has taught him to insinuate.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: It shall
But haste the confirmation of our loves,
and ripen the delights of marriage, Seleucus.

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.l: As I guest,
It cannot be too soon.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Tomorrow then we crown her, and invest
My son with majesty, 'tis to my wishes,
Beget a race of princes my Lisimachus.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Thy brow was made
To wear a golden circle, I'm transported,
Thou shalt rule her, and I will govern thee.

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.l: Although you be my father, that will not
Concern my obedience, as I take it. Enter Philocles, Lisander, and Antigonus.
Gentlemen,
Prepare yourselves for a solemnity
Will turn the kingdom into triumph, Epire
Look fresh tomorrow, 'twill become your duties
In all your glory to attend the Queen
At her coronation, she is pleased to make
The next day happy in our calendar,
My office doth expire, and my old blood
Renews with thought on't.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.l: And he so joyful to resign his regency,
There's some trick in't, I do not like these hasty
Proceedings, and whirls of state, they have commonly
As strange and violent effects; well, heaven ▪ save the Queen.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Heaven save the Queen say I, and send her a sprightly
Bedfellow for the protector, let him pray for
Himself, he is like to have no benefit of my devotion.

sp.speaker: Cas,
sp.l: But this doth quicken my old heart Lisimachus,
There is not any step into her throne,
But is the same degree of thy own state;
Come gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.l: What heretofore could happen to mankind
Was with much pain to climb to heaven, but in
Sophia's marriage of all Queens the best,
Heaven will come down to earth ▪ to make me blessed.

div.head: Actus secundus.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: To travel,
I know you see me, but to take your leave,
But I must never yield to such an absence.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I prithee leave thy fears, I am commanded
Toth' contrary, I wonot leave thee now.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I am very glad, for trust me, I could think
Of thy departure with no comfort, thou
Art all the joy I have, half of my soul;
But I must thank the Queen now for thy company,
I prithee what could make thee so desirous
To be abroad?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Only to get an appetite
To thee Polidora.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: Nay, prithee do not so mistake thy servant.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Perhaps you surfeit with my love.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Although I have no beauty to compare
With the best faces, I have a heart above
All competition.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Thou art jealous now;
Come, let me take the kiss I gave thee last,
I am so confident of thee, no lip
Has ravished it from thine; I prithee come
To court.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: There is the throne for beauty.

sp.speaker: Arc,
sp.l: There's none will hurt,
Or dare but think an ill to Polidora,
The greatest will be proud to honour thee.
Thy luster wants the admiration here:
there thou wot shine indeed, and strike a reverence
Into the gazer.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: No praise of thee can be thought so, thy virtue
Will deserve all, I must confess, we courtiers
Do oftentimes commend to show our art,
There is necessity sometimes to say,
This madam breathes Arabian gums,
Amber and cassia; though while we are praising,
We wish we had no nostrils to take in
The offensive steam of her corrupted lungs.
Nay, some will swear they love their mistress,
Would hazard lives and fortunes, to preserve
One of her hairs brighter than Berenice's;
Or young Apollo's, and yet after this,
A favour from another toy would tempt him
To laugh, while the officious hangman whips
Her head off.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I am none of these,
Nay, there are women Polidora too
That can do pretty well at flatteries;
Make men believe they dote, will languish for 'em,
Can kiss a jewel out of one, and dally
A carcanet of diamonds from another,
Weep into th'bosom of a third, and make
Him drop as many pearls; they count it nothing
To talk a reasonable heir within ten days
Out of his whole estate, and make him mad
He has no more wealth to consume.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: You'll teach me
To think I may be flattered in your promises,
Since you live where this art is most professed.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I dare not be so wicked Polidora,
The infant errors of the court I may
Be guilty off, but never to abuse
So rare a goodness, nor indeed did ever
Converse with any of those shames of court,
To practise for base ends; be confident
my heart is full of thine, and I so deeply
Carry the figure of my Polidora,
It is not in the power of time or distance ▪
To cancel it, by all that's blessed I love thee:
Love thee above all women, dare invoke
A curse when I forsake thee.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Let it be some
Gentle one.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Teach me an oath I prithee,
One strong enough to bind, if thou dost find
Any suspicion of my faith, or else
Direct me in some horrid imprecation
When I forsake thee, for the love of other
Woman, may heaven reward my apostasy
To blast my greatest happiness on earth,
And make all joys abortive.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Revoke these hasty syllables, they carry
To great a penalty for breach of love
To me, I am not worth thy suffering,
You do not know what beauty may invite
Your change, what happiness may tempt your eye
And heart together.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Should all the graces of your sex conspire
In one, and she should court me, with a dower
Able to buy a kingdom when I give
My heart from Polidora.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I suspect not,
And to requite thy constancy I swear.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: 'Twere sin to let thee waste thy breath
I have assurance of thy noble thoughts.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: My lord, your uncle hath been everywhere
Ith' court enquiring for you, his looks speak
Some earnest cause.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I am more acquainted with
Thy virtue then to imagine thou wilt not
Excuse me now, one kiss dismisses him
Whose heart shall wait on Polidora, prithee
Let me not wish for thy return too often,
my father.

sp.speaker: Nes.
sp.l: I met Arcadius in strange haste, he told me
He had been with thee.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Some affair too soon
Ravished him hence, his uncle sent for him
You came now from court: how looks the Queen
This golden morning?

sp.speaker: Nes.
sp.l: Like a bride, her soul
Is all on mirth, her eyes have quickening fires,
Able to strike a spring into the earth
In winter.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Then Lisimachus can haven
No frost in's blood, that lives so near her beams.

sp.speaker: Nes.
sp.l: His politic father, the protector smiles too,
Resolve to see the ceremony of the Queen
'Twill be a day of state,

sp.speaker: Nes.
sp.l: How ▪ not well? retire then, I must return
My attendance is expected, Polidora,
Be careful of thy health.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Dear nephew, if thou respect thy safety,
My honour, or my age, remove thyself,
Thy life's in danger.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Take horse, and instantly forsake the city,
Or else within some unsuspected dwelling,
Obscure thyself, stay not to know the reason.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Sir, I beseech your pardon, which ith' ▪ number
Of my offences unto any, should
Provoke this dishonourable flight?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I would when I petitioned for thy stay,
I had pleaded for thy banishment, thou knowest not
What threatens thee:

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I would desire to know it,
I am in no conspiracy of treason,
Have ravished no man's mistress, not so much
As given the lie to any, what should mean
Your strange and violent fears, I will not stir
Until you make me sensible I have lost
My innocence.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I must not live to see
Thy body full of wounds, it were less sin
To rip thy father's marble, and fetch from
The reverend vault his ashes, and disperse them
By some rude winds where none should ever find
The sacred dust, it was his legacy,
The breath he mingled with his prayers to heaven
I should preserve Arcadius, whose fate
He prophesied in death, would need protection,
Thou wot disturb his ghost, and call it to
Affright my dreams, if thou refuse to obey me.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: You more inflame me to inquire the cause
Of your distraction, and you'll arm me better
Than any coward flight by acquainting me
Whose malice aims to kill me, good sir tell me,

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Then prayers and tears assist me.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Arcadius,
Thou art a rash young man, witness the spirit
Of him that trusted me so much, I bleed,
Till I prevent this mischief.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I know your faces, but
Am not secure, I would not be betrayed.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: You wrong our hearts, who truly honour you.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: They say I must be killed.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: I know not, nor would I part with life so tamely.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: We dare engage ours in your quarrel, hide
Your sword, it may beget suspicion,
It's enough to question you.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I am confident,
Pray pardon me, come I despise all danger:
Yet a dear friend of mine, my uncle told me
He would not see my body full of wounds.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Yes, my honest uncle,
if my unlucky stars have pointed me
So dire a fate.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: There is some strange mistake in't.

sp.speaker: Ant
sp.l: Arcadius, the Queen would speak with you,
You must make haste.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Though to my death, I fly
Upon her summons, I give up my breath
Then willingly, if she command it from me.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: This does a little trouble me.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.l: I know not
What to imagine, something is the ground
Of this perplexity, but I hope there is not
Any such danger as he apprehends.

div.stage: Enter Queen, Lisimachus, Macarius, Eubulus, Seleucus, Arcadius, ladies and attendants, gent.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: We have already granted to Seleucus
And they shall try their valour if Arcadius
Have spirit in him to accept the challenge,
Our royal word is past.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: Madam my son knew not what he asked,
And you were cruel to consent so soon.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Wherein have I offended, to be robbed
At once of all the wealth I have, Arcadius
Is part of me.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: Seleucus' life and mine
Are twisted on one thread, both stand or fall
Together, hath the service for my country
Deserved but this reward, to be sent weeping
To my eternal home? Wast not enough
When I was young, to lose my blood in wars,
But the poor remnant that is scarcely warm
And faintly creeping through my withered veins
Must be let out to make you sport.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: How can
We that shall this morn seem the sacred oil
Fall on your virgin tresses ▪ hope for any
protection hereafter, when this day
You sacrifice the blood of them that pray for you.
Arcadius I prithee speak thyself,
It is for thee I plead.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: Seleucus, kneel
And say thou haste repented thy rash suit;
If ere I see thee fight, I be thus wounded,
How will the least drop forced from thy veins,
Afflict my heart.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Why, that's good;
Arcadius speak to her; hear him madam.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: If you call back this honour you have done me
I shall repent I live, do not persuade me
Seleucus thou art a noble enemy,
And I will love thy soul though I despair
Our bodies friendly conversation:
I would we were to tug upon some cliff,
Or like two prodigies ith' air, our conflict
Might generally be gazed at, and our blood
Appease our grandsires ashes.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Madam, my father says I have offended,
If so, I beg your pardon, but beseech you
For your own glory call not back your word.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: No more, we have resolved,
And since their courage is so nobly flamed,
This morning we'll behold the champions
Within the list, be not afraid, their strife
Will stretch so far as death, so soon as we
Are crowned prepare yourselves, Seleucus.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I have received another life in this high favour,
And may lose what nature gave me.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Arcadius to encourage thy young valour,
We give thee our father's sword.
Command it from our armoury; Lisimachus,
To our coronation.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I'll forfeit
my head for a rebellion then suffer it.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I am circled with confusions I'll done somewhat
My brains and friends assist me.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: But do you think they le fight indeed?

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.l: Perhaps
Her majesty will see about or two.
And yet 'tis wondrous strange, such spectacles
Are rare ith' court, and they were to skirmish naked
Before her, than there might be some excuse.
There is some gimcracks in't, the Queen is wise
Above her years.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.l: I cannot blame him, but my lord Eubulus
Returns, they are both troubled, 'las good men,
But our duties are expected, we forget.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: I must resolve, and yet things are not ripe,
My brains upon the torture.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: This may quit
The hazard of his person, whose least drop
Of blood is worth more than our families.
My lord Eubulus, I have thought a way
To stay the young men's desperate proceedings,
It is our cause they fight, let us beseech
The Queen, to grant us two the privilege
Of duel ▪ rather than expose their lives
To either's fury; it were pity they
Should run upon so black a destiny,
We are both old, and may be spared, a pair
Of fruitless trees, mossy and withered trunks,
That fill up too much room.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: Most willingly,
And I will praise her charity to allow it;
I have not yet forgotten to use a sword,
Let's lose no time, by this act, she will licence
Our souls to leave our bodies but a day,
Perhaps an hour the sooner; they may live
To do her better service, and be friends
When we are dead, and yet I have no hope
this will be granted, curse upon our faction.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: There's something oth' sudden struck upon
My imagination, that may secure us.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Name it, if no dishonour wait upon't
To preserve them, I'll accept any danger.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: There is no other way, and yet my heart
Would be excused but 'tis to save his life.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: In your ear I shall,
It sha'not make a noise if you refuse it.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Hum? though it stir my blood, I'll meet Arcadius,
If this preserve thee not, I must unseal
Another mystery.

div.stage: Enter Queen, Lisimachus, Cassander, Charilla, Lisander, Philocles, Antigonus.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: We owe to all your loves and will deserve
At least by our endeavours that none may
This day repent their prayers, my lord protector.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Madam I have no
Such title now, and am blessed to lose
That name so happily, I was but trusted
With a glorious burden.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: You have proved
Yourself our faithful counsellor, and must still
Protect our growing state, a kingdom's sceptre
Weighs down a woman's arm, this crown sits heavy
Upon my brow already, and we know
There's something more than mettle in this wreath,
Of shining glory, but your faith, and counsel,
That are familiar with mysteries,
And depths of state ▪ have power to make us fit
For such a bearing, in which both you shall
Do loyal service, and reward your duties.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: But yet my lords and gentlemen let nonē
mistake me, that because I urge your wisdoms,
I shall grow careless, and impose on you
The managing of this great province, no,
We will be active too, and as we are
In dignity above your persons, so,
The greatest portion of the difficulties
We call to us, you in your several places
Relieving us with your experience,
Observing in your best directions
All modesty, and distance, for although
We are but young, no action shall forfeit
Our royal privilege, or encourage any
Too unreverent boldness, as it will become
Our honour to consult, ere we determine
Of the most necessary things of state,
So we are sensible of a check,
But in a brow, that saucily controls
Our action, presuming on our years
As few, or frailty of our sex, that head
Is not secure that dares our power or justice.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: She has a brave spirit, look how the protector
Grows pale already.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: But I speak to you
Are perfect in obedience, and may spare
This theme, yet 'twas no immaterial
Part of our character, since I desire
All should take notice, I have studied
The knowledge of myself, by which I shall
Better distinguish of your worth and persons
In your relations to us.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.l: This language
Is but a threatening to somebody

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: But we miss some, that use not to absent
Their duties from us, where's Macarius?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Retired to grieve, your majesty hath given ▪
Consent Arcadius should enter list
Today with young Seleucus.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: We purposeEnter gentleman ▪
They shall proceed, what's he?

sp.speaker: Phil,
sp.l: A gentleman belonging to Seleucus, that gives notice
He is prepared, and waits your royal pleasure,

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: He was composed for action, give notice
To Arcadius, and admit the challenger,
Let other princes boast their gaudy tilting,
And mockery of battles, but our triumph
Is celebrated with true noble valour. Enter Seleucus, Arcadius at several doors, their pages before them bearing their targets.
Two young men spirited enough to have
Two kingdoms staked upon their swords, Lisimachus
Do not they excellently become their arms,
'Twere pity but they should do something more
Than wave their plumes. A shout within.
What noise is that?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: The people's joy to know us reconciled,
Is added to the jubilee of the day,
We have no more a faction but one heart,
Peace flow in every bosom.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: Throw away
These instruments of death, and like two friends
Embrace by our example.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: By our duties to yourself dear madam
Command them not advance, our houses from
This minute are incorporated, happy day
Our eyes at which before revenge look forth,
May clear suspicion, o my Arcadius!

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: We have found a nearer way to friendship madam,
Then by exposing them to fight for us.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: If this be faithful our desires are blessed,
We had no thought to waste, but reconcile
Your blood this was and we did prophesy
This happy chance, spring into either's bosom,
Arcadius and Seleucus, what can now
Be added to this day's felicity;
yes, there is something, is there not my lord?
While we are virgin Queen.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Ha, that string
Doth promise music.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I am yet my lords
Your single joy, and when I look upon,
What I have taken, to manage the great care
Of this most flourishing kingdom, I incline
To think, I shall do justice to myself,
If I chose one, whose strength and virtue may
Assist my undertaking, think you lords,
A husband would not help?

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.l: No question madam,
And he that you purpose to make so blessed
Must needs be worthy of our humblest duty,
It is the general vote.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: We will not then
Trouble ambassadors to treat with any
Princes abroad, within our own dominion,
Fruitful in honour, we shall make our choice;
And that we may not keep you over long
In the imagination, from this circle, we
Have purpose to elect one, whom I shall
Salute a King and husband.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Nor shall we in this action be accused
Of rashness, since the man we shall declare
Deserving our affection, hath been early
In our opinion, which had reason first
To guide it, and his known nobility
Long married to our thoughts, will justify
Our fair election.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Direct our duties madam to pray for him.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Arcadius you see from whence we come,
Pray lead us back, you may ascend.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Madam be charitable to your humblest creature,
Do not reward the heart, that falls in duty
Beneath your feet, with making me the burden
Of the court mirth, a mockery for pages,
'Twere treason in me but to think you mean thus.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Arcadius you must refuse my love,
Or shame this kingdom.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Is the wind in that corner?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: He kisses her, now by this day I am glad on't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Let him fret his heart strings.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.p: Is the day cloudy on the sudden?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Gentlemen
It was not my ambition, I durst never
Aspire so high in thought, but since her majesty
Hath pleased to call me to this honour, I
Will study to be worthy of her grace,
By whom I live.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: The church tomorrow shall
Confirm our marriage, noble Lisimachus
We'll find out other ways to recompense
Your love to us, set forward, come Arcadius.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: It must be so, and yet let me consider,

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: He insults already, policy assist me.
To break his neck.

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.l: Who would trust woman?
Lost in a pair of minutes, lost, how bright
A morning rose, but now, and now 'tis night?

div.head: Actus tertius.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: O where shall virgins look for faith hereafter?
If he prove false, after so many vows?
And yet if I consider, he was tempted
Above the strength of a young lover, two
Such glorious courting his acceptance, were
Able to make disloyalty no sin,
At least not seem a fault, a lady first,
Whose very looks would thaw a man more frozen
Than the Alps, quicken a soul more dead than winter.
Add to her beauty and perfection,
That she's a Queen, and brings with her a kingdom
Able to make a great mind forfeit heaven.
What could the frailty of Arcadius
Suggest to unspirit him so much, as not
To fly to her embraces, you were present
When she declared herself.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Tell me,
Did not he make a pause, when the fair Queen
A full temptation stood him?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Very little
My judgement could distinguish, she did no sooner
Propound, but he accepted.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: That was ill,
He might with honour stand one or two minutes,
Methinks it should have startled him a little,
To have remembered me, I have deserved
At least a cold thought, well pray give it him.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Not so,
But take a time when his joy swells him most,
When his delights are high and ravishing,
When you perceive his soul dance in his eyes,
when she that must be his, hath dressed her beauty
With all her pride, and sends a thousand Cupids
To call him to the tasting of her lip;
Then give him this, and tell him while I live,
I'll pray for him.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: There is no way but death.

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.l: That's black and horrid,
Consider sir it was her sin, not his;
I cannot accuse him, what man could carry
A heart so frozen, not to melt at such
A glorious flame? who could not fly to such
A happiness?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Have you ambition
To be a tame fool? Fee so vast an injury
And not revenge it? Make me not suspect
Thy mother for this sufferance, my son.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Hear a patient gull,
A property, thou hast no blood of mine,
If this affront provoke thee not, how canst
Be charitable to thyself, and let him live
To glory in thy shame? Nor is he innocent;
He had before crept slily into her bosom
And practised thy dishonour.

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.p: You begin to stir me sir.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: How else could she be guilty
Of such contempt of thee? and in the eye
Of all the kingdom, they conspired this stain,
When they had cunning meetings, shall thy love
And blooming hopes be scattered thus, and Lisimachus
Stand idle gazer?

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.l: What sir will his death
Advantage us, if she be false to me?
So irreligious, and to touch her person —
Pause we may be observed.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.l: 'Tis the protector
And his son.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Alas poor gentleman, I pity
His neglect, but am not sorry for his father.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I am yours gentlemen,
And should be happy to deserve your loves.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.l: In't sir, to enlarge your sufferings, i have
A heart doth wish
The Queen had known better to reward
Your love and merit.

sp.speaker: Lisa ▪
sp.l: If you would express
Your love to me; pray do not mention it,
I must obey my fate.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: She will be married
To tother gentleman for certain then?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: We are grown
Ridiculous, the pastime of the court:
Here comes another.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Like a neglected servant of his mistress.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: I would ask him a question.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Whether the Queen
As 'tis reported, loved him, he can tell
Whether she promised what they talk of, marriage,

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: I can resolve you that sir.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Then she's a woman, and your son;

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Not worthy his blood, and expectation,
If he be calm.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: The destinies, that's all your pardon sir,
I am Seleucus still, a poor shadow
Oth' world, a walking picture, it concerns
Not me, I am forgotten by my stars.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: The Queen with more discretion might ha' chosen
Thee.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Me? I cannot dance, and frisk with due activity,
My body is led, I have too much phlegm, what should
I do with a kingdom? no Arcadius
Becomes the cushion, and can please, yet setting
Aside the trick that ladies of blood look at,
Another man might make a shift to wear
Rich clothes, sit in the chair of state, and nod,
Dare venture on discourse, that does not trench
On compliment, and think the study of arms
And arts, more commendable in a gentleman
Than any galliard.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Arcadius,
And you were reconciled.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: We? yes, o yes,
But 'tis not manners now to say we are friends,
At our equality there had been reason,
But now, subjection is the word.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: They are not
Yet married.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I'll make no oath upon't,
My lord Lisimachus,
A word. you'll not be angry if I love you,
May not a bachelor be made a cuckold?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Lisimachus, this gentleman
Is worth our embrace, he's spirited,
And may be useful.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Hark you, can you tell
where's the best dancing-master? and you mean
To rise at court, practise to caper, farewell
The noble science, that makes work for cutlers,
It will be out of fashion to wear swords,
Masques, and devices welcome, I salute you.
Is it not pity any division
Should be heard out of music? O 'twill be
An excellent age of crotchets; and of canters.
Buy captains that like fools will spend your blood
Out of your country, you will be of less
Use then your feathers, if you return unmanned
You shall be beaten soon to a new march,
When you shall think it a discretion
To sell your glorious buffs to buy fine pumps,
And pantables, this is I hope no treason.

div.stage: Enter Arcadius' leading the Queen, Charia, eubulus, Lisander, philocles, Polidor a, servant.

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.l: Yes sir,
And show a patience above her injury.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: This honour is too much, madam assume
Your place, and let Arcadius wait still:
'Tis happiness enough to be your servant.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: This is not music
Sprightly enough, it feeds the soul with melancholy.
How says Arcadius?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Give me leave to think
There is no harmony but in your voice,
And not an accent of your heavenly tongue,
But strikes me into rapture, I incline
To think the tale of Orpheus no fable,
'Tis possible he might inchant the rocks,
And charm the forest, soften hell, hell itself
With his commanding lute, it is no miracle
To what you work, whose very breath conveys
the hearer into heaven, how at your lips,
Day winds gather perfumes, proudly glide away,
To disperse sweetness round about the world.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Not if I should say
Nature had placed you here the creatures wonder,
And her own spring, from which all excellence
On earth's derived, and copied forth, and when
The character of fair, and good in others
Is quite worn out, and lost, looking on you
It is supplied, and you alone made mortal
To feed and keep alive all beauty.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Ha, ha, can you endure it gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Nay ask him what he means, mine is a down
Right laugh.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: At such bright eyes the stars do light themselves,
At such a forehead swans renew their white,
From such a lip the morning gathers blushes.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: The morning is more modest than thy praises,
What a thing does he make her?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: And when you fly to heaven and leave this world
No longer maintenance of goodness from you,
Than poetry shall lose all use with us,
And be no more, since nothing in your absence
Is left, that can be worthy of a verse.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.p: Have you ambition to be punished sir?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I need not, 'twas punishment
Enough to hear him make an idol of you, he left
Out the commendation of your patience, I was a little
Moved in my nature to hear his rodomontadoes, and
Make a monster of his mistress, which I pitied first,
But seeing him proceed, I guest he brought you
Mirth with his inventions, and so made bold to laugh at it.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: You are saucy,
We'll place you where you sha'not be so merry,
Take him away.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: Let me plead for his pardon.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I would not owe my life so poorly, beg thy own
When you are King you cannot bribe your destiny.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: Good madam hear me, I fear he is distracted,
Brave boy, thou shouldst be master of a soul
Like his: thy honours more concerned.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: 'Tis charity,
A way wi' me, 'Boy madam?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: These and a thousand more affronts I must
Expect: your favours draw them all upon me;
In my first state I had no enemies,
I was secure while I did grow beneath
This expectation, humble valleys thrive with
Their bosoms full of flowers, when the hills melt
With lightning, and rough anger of the clouds,
Let me retire.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: And can Arcadius
At such a breath be moved, I had opinion
Your courage durst have stood a tempest for
Our love, can you for this incline to leave
What other princes should in vain have sued for?
How many lovers are in Epire now
Would throw themselves on danger, not expect
One enemy, but empty their own veins,
And think the loss of all their blood rewarded,
to have one smile of us when they are dying?
And shall this murmur shake you?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Not dear madam,
My life is such a poor despised thing,
In value your least graces, that
To lose it were to make myself a victory,
It is not for myself I fear: the envy
Of others cannot fasten wound in me
Greater, than that your goodness should be checked
So daringly.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Let not those thoughts afflict thee
While we have power to correct the offences
Arcadius be mine, this shall confirm it.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I shall forget
And lose my way to heaven, that touch had been
Enough to have restored me, and infused
A spirit of a more celestial nature,
After the tedious absence of my soul,
O bless me not too much, one smile a day
Would stretch my life to mortality,
Poets that wrap divinity in tales,
Look here, and give your copies forth of angels,
What blessing can remain?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Place then some horrors in the way
For me, not you to pass, the journey's end
Holds out such glories to me, I should think
Hell but a poor degree of suffering for it,
What's that some petition, a letter to me. You had a Polidora, ha, that's all.
Ith' minute when my vessels new launched forth,
With all my pride and silken wings about me
I strike upon a rock: what power can save me?
You had a Polidora; there's a name
Killed with grief I can so soon forget her

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: She did impose on me this service sir,
And while she lives she says she'll pray for you.

sp.speaker: Arc
sp.l: She lives
that's well, and yet 'twere better, for my fame,
And honour she were dead, what fate hath placed me
Upon this fearful precipice?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I must resolve, my faith is violated
Already, yet poor loving Polidora
Will pray for me, she says, to think she can
Render me hated to myself, and every
Thought's a tormentor, let me then be just.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: That voice prevails again, o Polidora,
Thou must forgive Arcadius, I dare not
Turn rebel to a Princess, I shall love
Thy virtue, but a kingdom has a charm
To excuse our frailty, dearest madam.

div.stage: Enter Macarius, and a Bishop, Casander.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: My lord Macarius we did want your person,
There's something in our joys wherein you share.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: This you intend your highness' wedding day.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Save you labour
I have brought a priest to meet you.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: To tell you that you must not marry.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Madam 'tis a rule
First made in heaven, and I mun needs declare
You and Arcadius must tie no knot
Of man and wife.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Joy has transported him,
Or age has made him dote, Macarius
Provoke us not too much, you will presume
Above our mercy.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I'll discharge my duty,
Could your frown strike me dead, my lord you know
Whose character this is.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: It is Thedosius.
Your grace's father.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Fear not, I'll cross this match.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Uncle d'ye know what you do, or what we are
Going to finish, you will not break the neck of my glorious
Fortune, now my foots ith' stirrups and mounting,
Throw me over the saddle, I hope you'll let one
Be a King, madam 'tis as you say,
My uncle is something crazed, there is a worm
In's brain, but I beseech you pardon him, he is
Not the first of your counsel, that has talked
Idly, d'ye hear my lord Bishop, I hope
You have more religion than to join with him
To undo me.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Not I sir, but I am commanded by oath,
And conscience to speak truth.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: If your truth should do me any harm, I shall never
Be in charity with a croziers staff, look to't.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Deliver to me an infant with this writing,
To which this reverend father is a witness.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: This he whom we so long thought dead, a child.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: But what should make my father to trust him
To your concealment? give abroad his death, and bury
An empty coffin?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: A jealousy he had
upon Cassander, whose ambitious brain
He feared would make no conscience to depose
His son, to make Lisimachus King of Epire.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: He made no scruple to expose me then
To any danger?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: He secured you madam
By an early engagement of your affection
To Lisimachus, exempt this testimony,
Had he been Arcadius, and my nephew
I needed not obtrude him on the state,
Your love and marriage had made him King
Without my trouble, and saved that ambition
There was necessity to open now
His birth, and title.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: What riddles are these, whom do they talk of?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Congratulate your return to life, and honour,
And as becomes us, with one voice salute you
Demetrius King of Epire.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I am no uncle, sir, this is your sister,
I should have suffered incest to have kept you
Longer ith' dark, love, and be happy both,
My trust is now discharged.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: But do not mock me gentlemen,
May I be bold upon your words to say
I am prince Thedosius' son.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: You'll justify it?
Sister I am very glad to see you.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: I am to find a brother, and resign my glory,
My triumph is my shame.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Gentlemen I owe
Unto your loves, as large acknowledgement
As to my birth for this great honour, and
My study shall be equal to be thought
worthy of both.

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.p: There will be the less charge for my monument.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: This must not be, fit fast young King.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: My sister should have been my bride, that name
Puts me in mind of Polidora, ha?
Lisander, Philocles, gentlemen,
If you will have me think your hearts allow me
Thedosius' son, o quickly snatch some wings,
Express it in your haste to Polidora,
Tell her what title is new dropped from heaven
To make her rich; only created for me,
Give her the ceremony of my Queen,
With all the state that may become our bride
Attend her to this throne; are you not there?
Yet stay, 'tis too much pride to send for her,
We'll go ourself, no honour is enough
For Polidora, to redeem our fault
Salute her gently from me, and upon
Your knee, present her with this diadem,
'Tis our first gift, tell her Demetrius follows
To be her guest, and give himself a servant
To her chaste bosom, bid her stretch her heart
To meet me, I am lost in joy and wonder.

div.head: Actus quartus.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Where's the captain of the castle?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Give him knowledge we expect him.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: He is my creature, fear not,
And shall run any course that we proposed.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: My lord, I like the substance of your plot,
'Tis promising, but matters of this consequence
Are not so easily perfect, and it does
Concern our heads to build upon secure
Principles, though Seleucus, I confess,
Carry a high, and daring spirit in him,
'Tis hard to thrust upon the state new settled
Any impostor, and we know not yet
Whether he'll undertake to play the prince;
Or if he should accept it, with what cunning
He can behave himself.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: My lord, affairs
Of such a glorious nature, are half finished
When they begin with confidence.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Admit
He want no art, nor courage, it must rest
Upon the people to receive his title,
And with what danger their uncertain breath
May flatter ours, Demetrius scarcely warm
In the King's seat, I may suspect.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: That reason
Makes for our part, for if it be so probable,
That young Demetrius should be living, why
May not we work them to believe Leonatus
The eldest son was by some trick preserved
And now would claim his own: there were two sons,
Who in their father's life we supposed dead,
May not we find a circumstance to make
This seem as clear as tother, let the vulgar
Be once possessed, we'll carry Epire from ▪
Demetrius, and the world.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: I could be pleased
To see my son a King. Enter Poleanus.
The captain's here.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: We come to visit your late prisoner. ▪
I will not doubt, but you entreat him fairly
he will deserve it for himself, and you
Be fortunate in any occasion
To have expressed your service.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Sir, the knowledge
Of my honourable lord his father, will
Instruct me to behave myself with all
Respects becoming me, to such a son.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: These things will least
Oblige you, but how bears he his restraint?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: As one whose soul's above it.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: With contempt rather of the great command
Which made him prisoner, he will talk sometimes
So strangely to himself.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Why was I born to be a subject? 'tis
Soon answered, sure my father was no prince,
That's all, the same ingredience use to make
A man, as active, though not royal blood
Went to my composition, and I
Was gotten with as good a will perhaps,
And my birth cost my mother as much sorrow,
As I had been born an emperor.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: While I look
Upon him, something in his face presents
A King indeed.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: He does resemble much
Thedosius too.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Whose son we would pretend him,
This will advance our plot,

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: 'Tis but a name,
And mere opinion, that prefers one man
Above another, I'll imagine then
I am a prince , or some brave thing on earth,
And see what follows, but it must not be
My single voice will carry it, the name
Of King must be attended with a troop
of acclamations, on whose airy wings
He mounts, and once exalted threatens heaven,
And all the stars: how to acquire this noise,
And be the thing I talk of, men have rise
From a more cheap nobility to empires,
From dark originals, and sordid blood,
Nay some that had no fathers, sons of the earth,
And flying people, have aspired to kingdoms,
Made nations tremble, any have practised frowns
To awe the world, their memory is glorious,
And I would hug them in their shades, but what's
All this to me; that am I know not what,
And less in expectation?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Will you assist, and run a fate with us.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Command my life, I owe it to your favour.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Arcadius was once as far from being
As I, and had we not so cunningly
Been reconciled, or one, or both had gone
To seek our fortunes in another world;
What's the device now? If my death be next,
The summons shall not make me once look pale.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Chide your too vain suspicions, we bring
A life, and liberty, with what else can make
Thy ambition happy, thou'st a glorious flame
We come to advance it.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Have but a will,
And be what thy own thoughts dare prompt thee to,
A King.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: You do not mock me gentlemen,
You are my father sir.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: This minute shall
Declare it my Seleucus, our hearts swelled
With joy, with duty rather, o my boy ▪

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Seleucus, stay thou art too incredulous,
let not our faith, and study to exalt thee,
Be so rewarded.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: I pronounce thee King
Unless thy spirit be turned coward, and
Thou faint to accept it.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Although the Queen since she sent me hither
Were gone to heaven I know not how
That title could devolve to me.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: We have
No Queen, since he that should have married her,
Is proved her youngest brother, and now King
In his own title.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Thank you gentlemen,
There's hope for me.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Why, you dare fight with ▪ him
And need be, for the kingdom.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: With Arcadius,
If you'll make stakes, my life against his crown,
I'll fight with him, and you, and your fine son,
And all the courtiers one after another.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: I am of your lordship's mind, so fare you well

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: What? that you have betrayed me,
Do, tell your King, my life is grown a burden,
And I'll confess, and make your souls look pale,
To see how nimble mine shall leap this battlement
Of flesh, and dying, laugh at your poor malice.

sp.speaker: Omnes ▪
sp.p: No more, long ▪ live Leonatus' King of Epire.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Be bold and be a King, our brains have been
Working to raise you to this height, here are
None but friends, dare you but call yourself
Leonatus, and but justify with confidence
What we'll proclaim you, if we do not bring
The crown to your head, we will forfeit ours.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: The state is in distraction, Arcadius
Is proved a King, there was an elder brother,
If you dare but pronounce, you are the same,
Forget you are my son.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: These are no trifles, sir, all is plotted
To assure your greatness, if you will be wise,
And take the fair occasion that's presented.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Arcadius, you say, is lawful King,
And now to depose him, you would make me
An elder brother, is't not so?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Nay, right or wrong, if this be your true meaning.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I'll venture mine, but with your pardon,
Whose brain was this? from whom took this plot life?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: And you are of his mind? and you? and think
This may be done?

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: The destinies shall not cross us, if you have
Spirit to undertake it.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Undertake it?
I am not used to compliment, I'll owe
My life to you, my fortunes to your lordship,
Compose me as you please, and when you've made
Me what you promise, you shall both divide
Me equally, one word my lord, I had rather
Live in the prison still, then be a propency
To advance his politic ends.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: So, so, I see Demetrius' heels already
Tripped up, and I'll dispatch him out oth' way,
Which gone, I can depose this at my leisure
Being an impostor, than my son stands fair,
And may piece with the Princess, we lose time,
What think you, if we first surprise the court,
While you command the castle, we shall curb
All opposition.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: Let's proclaim him first.
I have some faction, the people love me,
They gained to us, we'll fall upon the court.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Unless Demetrius yield himself he bleeds.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Who dares call treason sin, when it succeeds?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Madam, you are too passionate, and lose
The greatness of your soul, with the expense
Of too much grief, for that which providence
Hath eased you of, the burden of a state
Above your tender bearing.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Thar't a fool,
And canst not reach the spirit of a lady,
Born great as I was, and made only less
By a too cruel destiny, above
Our tender bearing? what goes richer to
The composition of man, than ours?
Our soul as free, and spacious, our heart's
As great, our will as large, each thought as active,
And in this only man more proud than we,
That would have us less capable of empire,
But search the storeys, and the name of Queen
Shines bright with glory, and some precedents
Above man's imitation.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: I grant it
For the honour of our sex, nor have you, madam,
By any weakness forfeited command,
He that succeeds, in justice, was before you,
And you have gained more in a royal brother
Than you could lose by your resign of Epire.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: This I allow Charilla, I ha' done;
'Tis not the thought I am deposed afflicts me,
At the same time I feel a joy to know
My brother living: no, there is another
Wound in me above cure.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: Canst find me out a surgeon for that?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: O do not injure
Your own clear innocence.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Do not flatter me,
I have been guilty of an act, will make
All love in women questioned, is not that
A blot upon a virgin's name? my birth
Cannot extenuate my shame, I am
Become the stain of Epire.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: 'Tis but
Your own opinion, madam, which presents
Something to fright yourself, which cannot
Be in the same shape so horrid to our sense.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Thou wod'st but canst not appear ignorant,
Did not the court, nay, the whole kingdom, take
Notice I loved Lisimachus?

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: No. I was false
Though counselled by my father to affect him,
I had my politic ends upon Cassander,
To be absolute Queen, flattering his son with hopes
Of love and marriage, when that very day
I blush to think I wronged Lisimachus,
That noble gentleman, but heaven punished me;
For though to know Demetrius was a blessing,
Yet who will not impute it my dishonour.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Madam, you yet may recompense Lisimachus,
If you affect him now, you were not false
To him whom then you loved not, if you can
Find any gentle passion in your soul
To entertain his thought, no doubt his heart,
Though sad, retains a noble will to meet it,
His love was firm to you, and cannot be
Unrooted with one storm.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: He will not sure
Trust any language from her tongue that mocked him,
Although my soul doth weep for't, and is punished
To love him above the world.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: He's here
As fate would have him reconciled, be free,
And speak your thoughts.

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.l: If madam I appear
Too bold, your charity will sign my pardon:
I heard you were not well, which made me haste
To pay the duty of an humble visit.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: You do not mock me sir.

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.l: I am confident
You think me not so lost to manners, in
The knowledge of your person, to bring with me
Such rudeness, I have nothing to present,
But a heart full of wishes for your health,
And what else may be added to your happiness.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: I thought you had been sensible.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: A man of understanding, can you spend
One prayer for me, remembering the dishonour
I have done Lisimachus?

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.l: Nothing can deface that part of my
Religion in me, not to pray for you.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: It is not then impossible you may
Forgive me too, indeed I have a soul
Is full of penitence, and something else,
If blushing would allow to give't a name.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Love, a love that should redeem
My past offence, and make me white again.

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.l: I hope no sadness can possess your thoughts
For me, I am not worthy of this sorrow,
But if you mean it any satisfaction
For what your will hath made me suffer, 'tis
But a strange overflow of charity,
To keep me still alive, be yourself madam,
And let no cause of mine, be guilty of
This rape upon your eyes, my name's not worth
The least of all your tears.

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.l: Although I may
Suspect a woman's smile hereafter, yet
I would believe their wet eyes, and if this
Be what you promise, for my sake, I have
But one reply.

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.l: I have now
Another mistress.

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.l: To whom I have made
Since your revolt from me, a new chaste vow,
Which not the second malice of my fate
Shall violate, and she deserves it madam,
Even for that wherein you are excellent,
Beauty, in which she shines equal to you
Her virtue, if she but maintain what now
She is mistress of, beyond all competition,
So rich it cannot know to be improved,
At least in my esteem, I may offend,
But truth shall justify, I have not flattered her,
I beg your pardon, and to leave my duty
Upon your hand, all that is good flow in you.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Did he not say Charilla, that he had
Another mistress?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Such a sound methought
Came from him.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Let's remove, here's too much air,
The sad note multiplies.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Take courage madam,
And my advice, he has another mistress,
If he have twenty, be you wise, and cross him
With entertaining twice as many servants,
And when he sees your humour he'll return,
And sue for any livery, grieve for this,
It must be she, 'tis Polidora has
Taken his heart, she live my rival,
How does the thought inflame me.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: And yet she does but justly, and he too;
I would have robbed her of Arcadius' heart,
And they will both have this revenge on me,
But something will rebel.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: The house is desolate, none comes forth to meet us,
She's slow to entertain us, Philocles,
I prithee tell me, did she wear no cloud
Upon her brow, waste freely that she said
We should be welcome.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: To my apprehension,
Yet 'tis my wonder she appears not.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.l: She nor any other,
Sure there's some conceit
To excuse it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Stay, who's this? observe what follows?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Fortune? some mask to entertain you sir.

div.stage: Enter fortune crowned, attended with youth, health, and pleasure.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Not yet? what silence doth inhabit here?
No preparation to bid fortune welcome!
Fortune the genius of the world, have we
Descended from our pride, and state to come
So far attended with our darlings, youth
Pleasure, and health, to be neglected thus?
Sure this is not the place? call hither fame.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Know,
Who dwells here.

sp.speaker: Fame
sp.l: Once more I report great Queen,
This is the house of love.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: It cannot be,
This place has too much shade, and looks as if
It had been quite forgotten of the spring,
And sun beams love, affect society
And heat, here all is cold as the hairs of winter,
no harmony to catch the busy ear
Of passengers, no object of delight,
To take the wand'ring eyes, no song, no groan
Of lovers, no complaint of willow garlands,
Love has a beacon upon his palace top
Of flaming hearts, to call the weary pilgrim
To rest, and dwell with him, I see no fire
To threaten, or to warm, can love dwell here?

sp.speaker: Fame
sp.l: If there be noble love upon the world,
Trust fame, and find it here.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Make good your boast
And bring him to us.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.l: I told you sir we should have some device,Enter love.
There's Cupid now, that little gentleman,
Has troubled every mask at court this seven year.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Welcome to love, how much you honour me!
It had become me, that upon your summons
I should have waited upon mighty fortune,
But since you have vouchsafed to visit me;
All the delights love can invent, shall flow
To entertain you, music through the air
Shoot your enticing harmony.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: We came to dance and revel with you

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I am poor
In my ambition, and want thought to reach
How much you honour love.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: What intrusion's this?
Whom do you seek here.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Fortune is come to visit us.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: And has
Corrupted love, is this thy faith to her,
On whom we both wait, to betray her thus
to fortune's triumph, take her giddy wheel,
And be no more companion to honour
I blush to know thee, who'll believe there can
Be truth in love hereafter?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I have found
My eyes, and see my shame, and with it, this
Proud sorceress, from whom, and all her charms,
I fly again to honour, be my guard,
Without thee I am lost and cannot boast,
The merit of a name.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Despised? I shall
Remember this affront.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: What moral's this? Exeunt.Enter honour with the crown upon a mourning cushion.
What melancholy object strikes a sudden
Chillness through all my veins, and turns me ice?
It is the same I sent, the very same,
As the first pledge of her ensuing greatness,
Why in this mourning livery, if she live
To whom I sent it? ha, what shape of sorrow? Enter Polidora in mourning.
It is not Polidora, she was fair
Enough, and wanted not the setting off
With such a black, if thou beest Polidora,
Why mourns my love? it neither does become
Thy fortune nor my joys.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: But it becomes
My griefs, this habit fits a funeral,
And it were sin, my lord, not to lament
A friend new dead.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And I yet living? can
A sorrow enter but upon thy garment,
Or discomplexion thy attire, whilst I
Enjoy a life for thee? who can deserve
Weighed with thy living comforts, but a piece
Of all this ceremony? give him a name

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: A gentleman that loved me dear once,
And does compel these poor, and fruitless drops,
Which willingly would fall upon his hearse,
To embalm him twice.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: And are you sure he's dead?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: As sure as you're living sir, and yet
I did not close his eyes, but he is dead,
And I shall never see the same Arcadius,
He was a man so rich in all that's good,
At least i thought him so, so perfect in
The rules of honour, whom alone to imitate
Were glory in a prince, nature herself
Till his creation wrought imperfectly,
As she had made but trial of the rest,
To mould him excellent.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And is he dead?
Come, shame him not with praises, recollect
Thy scattered hopes, and let me tell my best,
And dearest Polidora, that he lives,
Still lives to honour thee.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Look here.
Am not I worth your knowledge?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: And my duty,
You are Demetrius King of Epire, sir.
I could not easily mistake him so,
To whom I gave my heart.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Mine is not changed,
But still hath fed upon thy memory,
These honours, and additions of state
Are lent me for thy sake, be not so strange,
Let me not lose my entertainment now
I am improved, and raised unto the height,
Beneath which, I did blush to ask thy love.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Give me your pardon sir, Arcadius,
At our last meeting without argument
To move him more than his affection to me,
vowed he did love me; love me 'bove all women,
And to confirm his heart was truly mine,
He wished, I tremble to remember it,
When he forsook his Polidora's love,
That heaven might kill his happiness on earth:
Was not this nobly said, did not this promise
A truth to shame the turtles?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And his heart
Is still the same, and I thy constant lover.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Give me your leave I pray, I would not say
Arcadius was perjured, but the same day
Forgetting all his promises, and oaths,
While yet they hung upon his lips, for sooke me,
D'ye not remember this too, gave his faith
From me, transported with the noise of greatness,
And would be married to a kingdom.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: But heaven permitted not I should dispose
What was ordained for thee.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: It was not virtue
In him, for sure he found no check, no sting
In his own bosom, but gave freely all
The reins to blind ambition.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I am wounded,
The thought of thee ith' throng of all my eyes,
Like poison poured in nectar, turns me frantic,
Dear, if Arcadius have made a fault,
Let not Demetrius be punished for't,
He pleads that ever will be constant to thee.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Shall I believe man's flatteries again,
Lose my sweet rest, and peace of thought again,
Be drawn by you, from the straight paths of virtue
Into the maze of love.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I see compassion in thy eye, that chides me
If I have either soul, but what's contained
Within these words ▪ or if one syllable
Of their full force, be not made good by me,
May all relenting thoughts in you take end,
And thy disdain be doubled, from thy pardon,
I'll count my coronation, and that hour
Fix with a rubric in my calendar,
As an auspicious time to entertain
Affairs of weight with princes, think who now
Entreats thy mercy, come thou shalt be kind,
And divide titles with me

sp.speaker: Pol,
sp.l: Hear me sir,
I loved you once for virtue, and haven not
A thought so much unguarded as to be won
From my truth, and innocence with any
Motives of state to affect you,
Your bright temptation mourns while it stays here
Nor can the triumph of glory, which made you
Forget me, so court my opinion back,
Were you no King, I should be sooner drawn
Again to love you, but 'tis now too late,
A low obedience shall become me best ▪
May all the joys I want
Still wait on you, if time hereafter tell you
That sorrow for your fault hath struck me dead,
May one soft tear drop from your eye, in 〈…〉 ty
Bedew my hearse, and I shall sleep securely
I have but one word more for goodness' sake,
For your own honour sir correct your passion
To her you shall love next, and I forgive you.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Her heart is frozen up, nor can warm prayers
Thaw it to any softness.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: You give your passion too much leave to triumph.
Seek in another what she denies.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Where's the King? o sir, you are undone,
A dangerous treason is a foot.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Cassander, and Eubulus have proclaimed
Another King, whom they pretend to be
Leonatus your elder brother, he that was,
but this morning prisoner in the castle.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: The easy Epirotes
Gather in multitudes to advance his title,
They have seized upon the court, secure your person
Whilst we raise power to curb this insurrection.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: We will not arm one man,
Speak it again, have I a brother living?
And must be no King.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: This news doth speak me happy, it exalts
My heart, and makes me capable of more
Than twenty kingdoms.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Will you not sir, stand
Upon your guard?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I'll stand upon my honour,
Mercy relieves me.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: The worlds too poor to bribe me, leave
Me all, lest you extenuate my fame, and I
Be thought to have redeemed it by your counsel,
You shall not share one scruple in the honour;
Titles may set a gloss upon our name,
But virtue only is the soul of fame.

div.head: Actus quintus.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.l: 'Tis a kingdom
Easily purchased, who will trust the faith
Of multitudes?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: It was his fault, that would
So tamely give his title to their mercy,
then new King has possession.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.l: And is like
To keep't, we are alone, what doffed think of
This innovation? is't not a fine lig?
A precious cunning in the late protector
To shuffle a new prince into the state.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I know not how they have shuffled, but my head on't
A false card is turned up trump, but fates look to't.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.p: Does he not carry it bravely.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Excellently.
Philocles Lisander.

sp.speaker: Phi. Lis.
sp.l: Your lordship's servants,
Are we not bound to heaven, for multiplying
These blessings on the kingdom.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Heaven alone
Works miracles my lord.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.l: I think your lordship
Had as little hope once, to see these princes
Revive.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Here we must place our thanks,
Next providence, for preserving
So dear a pledge.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: It is our pleasure
The number of our guard be doubled, give
A largesse to the soldiers; but dismiss not
The troops till we command.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: It will not please us otherwise, my lord,
We have tried your faith,

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.p: Does he not speak with confidence?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: My lords, and gentlemen, to whose faith we must
Owe next to heaven our fortune, and our safety,
After a tedious eclipse, the day
Is bright, and we invested in those honours,
Our blood, and birth did challenge.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: May no time
Be registered in our annals, that shall mention
One that had life to oppose your sacred person,

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Let them whose titles forged and flawed suspect
Their state's security, our right to Epire,
Heaven is obliged to prosper, treason has
No face so black to fright it, all my cares
Level to this, that I may worthily
Manage the province, and advance the honour
Of our dear country, and be confident,
If an expense of blood, may give addition
Of any happiness to you, I shall
Offer my heart the sacrifice, and rejoice
To make myself a ghost, to have inscribed
Upon my marble, but whose cause I died for.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Excellent prince,
In whom we see the copy of his father
None but the son of Theodosius,
Could have spoke thus.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You are pleased to interpret well,
Yet give me leave to say in my own justice,
