I have but expressed the promptness of my soul
To serve you all, but 'tis not empty wishes
Can satisfy our mighty charge, a weight
Would make an Atlas double, a King's name
Doth sound harmoniously to men at distance,
And those who cannot penetrate beyond
The bark, and outskin of a common wealth,
Or state, have eyes but ravished with the ceremony
That must attend a prince, and understand not
What cares allay the glories of a crown,
But good Kings find and feel the contrary,
You have tried, my lord ▪ the burden, and can tell
It would require a pilot of more years
To steer this kingdom, now imposed on me,
By justice of my birth.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I wish not life,
but to partake those happy days, which must
Succeed these fair proceedings, we are blessed,
But sir be sparing to yourself, we shall
Hazard our joys in you too soon, the burden
Of state affairs impose upon your counsel.
'Tis fitter that we waste our lives than you,
Call age too soon upon you with the trouble,
And cares that threaten such an undertaking,
Preserve your youth.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And choose you our protector,
Is't that you would conclude my lord? We will
Deserve our subjects' faith for our own sake,
Not sit an idle gazer at the helm

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: How observed you that,
Mark how Cassander's planet struck.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: He might have looked more calmly for all that
I begin to fear; but do not yet seem troubled.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: With what news travels his haste? I must secure
Myself betimes, not be a King in jest,
And wear my crown a tenant to their breath.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Demetrius sir, your brother,
With other traitors that oppose your claims
Are fled to the castle of Nestorius
And fortify.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: I said not so my lord.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: I'll have it thought so, hence.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Plant forces to batter
The walls, and in their ruin bring us word
They live not.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Let it work,
Were Demetrius dead, we easily might uncrown
This swollen impostor, and my son be fair
To piece with young Sophia, who I hear
Repents her late affront.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: Their lives may do
You service, let not blood stain your beginnings
The people not yet warm in their allegiance,
May think it worth their tumult to revenge it
with hazard of yourself.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Who dares but think it?
Yet offer first our mercy, if they yield,
Demetrius must not live, my lord your counsel,
What if he were in heaven?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: You have my consent,
You sha'not stay long after him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Sophia is
Not my sister,
To prevent all that may endanger us, we'll marry her
That done no matter though we stand discovered,
For in her title then we are King of Epire,
Without dispute.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Hum? in my judgement sir,
That wonot do so well.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: He countermines my plot: are you so cunning

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Best say I am no King, but some impostor
Raised up to gull the state.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Very fine to have said within
Few hours you'd been no King, nor like to be,
Was not in the compass of high treason
I take it.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.p: Restrain your anger, the Kings moved, speak not ▪

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I will speak louder, do I not know him?
That self same hand that raised him to the throne
Shall pluck him from it, is this my reward?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Our guard, to prison with him,

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.p: Vouchsafe to hear me, great sir.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: How dares he be so insolent?
I ha' wrought myself into a fine condition,
D'ye know me gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Very well my lord;
how are we bound to heaven for multiplying
These blessings on the kingdom.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.p: Counsel did never blast a prince's ear.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Convey him to the sanctuary of rebels,
Nestorius' house, where our proud brother has
Ensconced himself, they'll entertain him lovingly,
He will be a good addition to the traitors,
Obey me or you die for't, what are Kings
When subjects dare affront 'em.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I shall vex
Thy soul for this.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Away with him, when Kings
Frown, let offenders tremble, this flows not
From any cruelty in my nature, but
The fate of an usurper, he that will
Be confirmed great without just title to it,
Must lose compassion, know what's good, not do it.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I attend her highness. Enter Sophia.
How much your grace honours your humble servant

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: Do you but hope? he came to be your guest.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: We are all his whilst he is pleased to honour
This poor roof with his royal presence madam.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: I came to ask your pardon Polidora,

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: You never madam trespassed upon me,
Wrong not your goodness.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: I can be but penitent,
Unless you point me out some other way
To satisfy.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Dear madam do not mock me.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: There is no injury like that to love,
I find it now in my own sufferings,
but though I would have robbed thee of Arcadius'
Heaven knew a way to reconcile your hearts,
And punished me in those joys you have found,
I read the story of my loss of honour,
Yet can rejoice, and heartily, that you
Have met your own again.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: He is found to himself and honour,
He is my King, and though I must acknowledge
He was the glory of my thoughts, and I
Loved him as you did madam, with desire
To be made his, reason, and duty since,
Formed me to other knowledge, and I now
Look on him without any wish of more
Than to be called his subject.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Has he made
Himself less capable by being King.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: With your pardon madam.
Love in that sense you mean, lest Polidora
When he forsook Arcadius, I disclaim
All ties between us, more than what a name
Of King must challenge from my obedience.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: This does confirm my jealousy, my heart,
For my sake madam, has he lost his value?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Let me beseech your grace, I may have leave
To answer in some other cause, or person,
This argument but opens a sad wound
To make it bleed a fresh, we may change this
Discourse, I would elect some subject, whose
Praises may more delight your care then this
Can mine; let's talk of young Lisimachus.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Well, you were talking of Lisimachus,
Pray give me your opinion of him.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Mine?
It will be much short of his worth, i think him
A gentleman so perfect in all goodness,
That if there be one in the world deserves
The best of women, heaven created him,
To make her happy.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: You have in a little, madam,
Expressed a volume of mankind, a miracle,
But all have not the same degree of faith,
He is but young.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: What mistress would desire
Her servant old? he has both spring to please
Her eye, and summer to return a harvest.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: He sets a beauty off more rich,
And she that's fair will love him, faint complexions
Betray effeminate minds, and love of change,
Two beauties in a bed, compound few men,
He's not so fair to counterfeit a woman,
Nor yet so black, but blushes may betray
His modesty.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: That praises him, and well compacted frame
Speaks temper, and sweet flow of elements,
Vast buildings are more oft for show then use,
I would not have my eyes put to the travel
Of many acres, ere I could examine
A man from head to foot, he has no great,
But he may boast, an eligant composition.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: I'll hear no more, you have so far outdone
My injuries to you, that I call back
My penitence, and must tell Polidora,
This revenge ill becomes her. Am I thought
So lost in soul to hear, and forgive this?
In what shade do I live? or shall I think
I have not at the lowest enough merit,
Setting aside my birth, to poise with yours,
Forgive my modest thoughts, if I rise up
my own defence, and tell this unjust lady
So great a winter hath not frozen yet
My cheek, but there is something nature planted,
That carries as much bloom, and spring upon't
As yours, what flame is in your eye, but may
Find competition here (Forgive again
My virgin honour,) what is in your lip,
To 'tice the enamoured soul, to dwell with more
Ambition than the yet unwithered blush
That speaks the innocence of mine. Enter Demetrius.
O brother?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I'll talk with you anon, my Polidora,
Allow thy patience till my breath recover
Which now comes laden with the richest news
Thy ear was ever blessed with.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Both your looks,
And voice express some welcome accident.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Guess what in wish could make me fortunate
And heaven hath dropped that on Demetrius.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: 'Twere sin to busy
Thy thoughts upon't, I'll tell thee that I could
Retain some part, 'tis too wide a joy
To be expressed so soon, and yet it falls
In a few syllables, thou wot scarce believe me,
I am no King.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Forbid? Heaven has relieved me with a mercy
I knew not how to ask, I have they say
An elder brother living, crowned already,
I only keep my name Demetrius,
Without desire of more addition,
Then to return thy servant.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: You amaze me,
Can you rejoice to be deposed:

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: It but
translates me to a fairer and better kingdom
In Polidora.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Did you not say,
Were I no King you could be drawn to love
Me again, that was consented to in heaven,
A kingdom first betrayed my ambitious soul
To forget thee, that, and the flattering glories,
How willingly Demetrius do resign,
The angels know, thus naked without titles
I throw me on thy charity, and shall
Boast greater empire to be thine again, then
To wear the triumphs of the world upon me.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Be not so careless of yourself, the people
Gather in multitudes, to your protection
Offering their lives, and fortunes, if they may
But see you sir, and hear you speak to 'em,
Accept their duties, and in time prevent
Your ruin.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: You trouble me with noise, speak Polidora

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: For your own sake preserve yourself,
My fears distract my reason.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Lord Lisimachus
With something that concerns your safety, is
Fled hither, and desires a present hearing.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: His soul is honest, be not sir a mad man,
And for a lady give up all our freedoms.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I'll say any thing here Lisimachus.

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.l: Sir, I come to yield
Myself your prisoner, if my father have
Raised an impostor to supplant your title
Which I suspect and inwardly do bleed for.
I shall not only by the tender of
myself declare my innocence, but either
By my unworthy life secure your person,
Or by what death you shall impose, reward
The unexpected treason.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Brave young man,
Did you not hear him brother?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Be witness madam, I resign my heart
It never was another's, you declare
Too great a satisfaction, I hope
This will destroy your jealousy,
Remember now your danger.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I despise it,
What fate dares injure me?

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Forgive me Polidora, you are happy,
My hopes are removed farther, I had thought
Lisimachus had meant you for his mistress,
'Tis misery to feed, and not know where
To place my jealousy.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Now 'tis too late,
You may be deaf, until the cannon make,
You find your sense, we are shut up now by
A troop of horse, thank yourself.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: They will
Admit conditions.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: News my lord Cassander sent by the new King.
To bear us company.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It does appear no otherwise, the soldiers
Declare how much they love him, by their noise
Of scorn, and joy to see him so rewarded.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You'll find it presently,
He curses the new King, talks treason 'gainst him
As nimble as he were in's shirt, he's here,

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: O let me beg until my knees take root
Ith' earth, sir, can you pardon me?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: For treason, desperate, most malicious treason
I have undone you sir ▪

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: It does appear
You had a will.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I'll make you all the recompense I can,
But ere you kill me hear me, know the man,
Whom I to serve my unjust ends, advanced
To your throne, is an impostor, a mere counterfeit,
Eubulus' son.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: It is not then our brother?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: An insolent usurper, proud, and bloody
Seleucus, is no leprosy upon me?
There is not punishment enough in nature
To quit my horrid act, I have not in
My stock of blood to satisfy with weeping,
Nor could my soul though melted to a flood
Within me, gush out tears to wash my stain off.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: How? an impostor, what will become on's now?
We are at his mercy.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Sir, the people's hearts
Will come to their own dwelling, when they see
I dare accuse myself, and suffer for it,
Have courage then young King, thy fate cannot
Be long compelled.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Rise, our misfortune
Carries this good, although it lose our hopes,
It makes you friend with virtue, we'll expect
What providence will do.

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.p: Our duties shall beg heaven still to preserve you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Our enemy desires some parley sir.

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.p: 'Tis not amiss to hear their proposition.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Thou art my angel, and canst best instruct me,
Boldly present ourselves, you'll with Cassander.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: And in death be blessedExit
To find your charity.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: They will not miss your presence, the small time
Is spent in asking of a question.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: Sit I have a suit to you.

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.p: To me? it must be granted.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: If you have
Cancelled your kind opinion of me,
Deny me not to know, who hath succeeded
Sophia in your heart. I beg the name
Of your new mistress.

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.l: You shall know her madam,
If but these tumults cease ▪ and fate allow us
To see the court again, I hope you'll bring
No mutiny against her, but this is
No time to talk of love, let me attend you.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: I must expect, till you are pleased to satisfy
My poor ▪ request ▪ conduct me at your pleasure ▪

div.stage: Enter Leonatus, Eubulus, Bishop, Lisander, Philocles.

sp.speaker: Leo ▪
sp.l: They are too slow, dispatch new messengers,
To entreat 'em fairly hither, I am ecstasied,
Were you witness for me too, is it possible
I am what this affirms ▪ true Leonatus ▪
And were you not my father, was I given
In trust to you an infant?

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: 'Tis a truth,
Our soul's bound to acknowledge ▪ you supplied
The absence and opinion of my son,
Who died but to make you my greater care
I know not of Demetrius, but supposed
Him dead indeed, as Epire thought you were,
your father's character doth want no testimony,
Which but compared with what concerns Demetrius
Will prove itself King Theodosius act,
Your royal father.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: I am subscribed to both his legacies
By oath obliged to secrecy, until
Thus fairly summoned to reveal the trust.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: Cassander had no thought you would prove thus.
To whose policy I gave this aim, although
He wrought you up to serve but as his engine
To batter young Demetrius, for it was
Your father's prudent jealousy, that made him
Give out your early deaths, as if his soul
Prophesied his own first, and feared to leave
Either of you to the unsafe protection,
Of one whose study would be to supplant
Your right, and make himself the King of Epire.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Your sister fair Sophia in your father's
Life, was designed to marry with Lisimachus
That guarded her, although she used some art
To quit her pupillage, and being absolute,
Declared love to Demetrius, which enforced
Macarius to discover first your brother.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: No more, lest you destroy again Leonatus ▪
With wonder of his fate, are they not come yet?
Something it was, I felt within my envy
Of young Demetrius' fortune, there were seeds
Scattered upon my heart, that made it swell
With thought of empire, princes I see cannot
Be totally eclipsed, but wherefore stays
Demetrius, and Sophia, at whose names
A gentle spirit walked upon my blood.

div.stage: Enter Demetrius, Polidora, Sophia, Macarius, Cassander ▪ Li 〈…〉 as ▪

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Then thus I fly into their bosoms,
Nature has rectified in me Demetrius,
The wanderings of ambition, our dear sister
You are amazed, I did expect it, read
assurance there, the day is big with wonder,

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Lisimachus, be dear to us,
Cassander, you are welcome too.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Not I,
I do not look for't, all this sha'not bribe
My conscience to your faction, and make
Me false again, Seleucus is no son
Of Theodosius, my dear countrymen
Correct your erring duties, and to that,
Your lawful King, prostrate yourselves, Demetrius
Doth challenge all your knees.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: All love and duty,
Flow from me to my royal King, and brother
I am confirmed.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: You are too credulous,
What can betray your faith so much?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Sophia, you appear sad, as if your will
Gave no consent to this day's happiness.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: No joy exceeds Sophia's for yourself.

sp.speaker: Lisi
sp.l: With your pardon sir, I apprehend
A cause that makes her troubled, she desires
To know what other mistress since her late
Unkindness, I have chosen to direct
My faith and service.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: And does our sister love Lisimachus?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He must not dare
To affront Sophia.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: How my shame confounds me,
I beg your justice, without pity on
My age.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Your penance shall be, to be faithful
To our state hereafter.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: May you live long and happy,
Leonatus' King of Epire.

sp.speaker: Leo,
sp.p: Our sister? is this another mistress sir?

sp.speaker: Lisi.
sp.l: It holds
To prove my thoughts were so when she began
Her sorrow for neglecting me, that sweetness
Deserved I should est 〈◊〉 her another mistress,
Then when she cruelly forsook Lysimachus,
Your pardon madam, and receive a heart
Proud with my first devotion to serve you

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: In this I am crowned again, now mine for ever.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You have deceived her happily,
Joy to you both.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: We are ripe for the same wishes,
Polidora's part of me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Heaven pour full joys upon you.

sp.speaker: Mac,
sp.l: We are all blessed,
There wants but one to fill your arms.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: My mistress,
And wife shall be my country, to which I
Was in my birth contracted, your love since
Hath played the priest to perfect what was ceremony
Though kingdoms, by just●tkes prove our own,
The subjects' hearts do best secure a crown.

lg.l: There is no coronation today.
Unless your gentle votes do crown our play,
If smiles appear within each lady's eye,
Which are the leading stars in this fair sky,
Our solemn day sets glorious, for then
We hope by their soft influence, the men
Will grace what they first shined on, make't appear,
(Both) how we please, and bless our covetous care
With your applause, more welcome than the bell,
Upon a triumph, bonfires, or what else
Can speak a coronation. And though I
Were late disposed and spoiled of majesty ▪
By the kind aid of your hands, gentlemen,
I quickly may be crowned a Queen again ▪

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
